title: Audio Commons ontology: a data model for an audio content ecosystem

author: Miguel Ceriani, Queen Mary, University of London

segmentation: Thank you David.
So I will talk about work we carried on together with George Patrick's.
That is the design of an ontology and it is an ontology to describe audio content, metadata and relationship relationships.
And what I would like to.
Convince you is that this ontology is useful, and I will try to give you some ideas of its design.
So the like big picture motivation of this ontology is that there is already a lot of audio content available online that is basically a subset or all the media content that you have.
We have audio video that it's like a huge part of the online traffic and a lot of these online audio content has already attached a lot of interesting.
Structured meta data.
An interesting relationships so that this could be used by a number of different users in number of different contexts to do creative use of these relationships.
Of these structured data.
But for that we need some data model to support the integration.
So this is like the big picture.
Motivation.
Now I'm going a bit more in the specific context.
If we develop this design and develop this ontology that is the Audio Commons project that is a European funded project and in which we foster to with.
So we aim sorry to foster the use of Creative Commons over your content so it's a bit more specific by finite user as well as professionals that work in audio production workflows.
So there is also in the case of Creative Commons audio audio content, there are some content providers out there and a lot of content that could be used.
But it's still not so easy to use this context in an integrated or flow of audio production, so we want to.
After this this use and browser all these audio content.
So the idea is to build this audio comments ecosystem.

In which there are some content providers, there are some agents that interact with this content providers, so can browse, search and then we produce their own content that will go in some repository of content and of course.
All this interaction has to be mediated by some common data model, so this is the role of the audio comments ontology.
So in our specific project there all is to really mediate and this interaction.
So what is the design method?
I will tell you briefly.

So basically we start from the specification of what is the scope and the audience of this data model, and then we did a user survey with potential users to get more information, research on existing data models, ontologies, then we proceed to the content conceptualization formalisation.
Of the ontology in owl.
Integration with existing ontologies.
Finally, we implemented a published it online and then finally we can use.
We are using it in our project and evaluating and updating it accordingly.
So it's a way it's also living data model in the sense that we believe, especially in the first phase of an ontology of a data Model 1 is.

The part for published that there is there should be an evolution according to the needs of the of the our specific project and hopefully more broadly to the Community that may be interested in using it.
So from the I'm not going to describe the user survey, you can find details in the paper from the user service we identify as some user use cases, some scenarios and so like for example.

The scenario which finite user like a cafe owner, want to look for music of a certain kind and or more like professional users like an audio producer that want to access high quality audio loops in hits digital audio workstation.
That is the software tool that he uses to produce audio and our game sound designer so it will be we have.
Other tools and also is looking for in this case effects that he may use in the games he's designing.

And based on these use cases, and obviously that the results of our survey and the research we've done, we establish some general requirements so that we need to represent the concept of an audio clip that is like the central concept of the of this ontology.
This published in some repository.
So along with the metadata like title, license, etc.
Then data.
About the signal, that is really the audio signal tease container that is the actual audio content and the multiple media resources in which this signal may be encoded.
So with possible different formats, different compressions, etc an we have to allow for multi fast classifications because we've seen that different users need different classifications sometimes.
Even multiple types of classifications at once, so we have to offer ways to classify audio according to different axis.

We have to support specifically want to support collection because it's something very common in audio content like could be tracked musical tracks in a in a music album as some sounds in a pack of sound.
And then we want this to be compatible with other existing specific models because.
We know that some people may be interested in some specific audio.
For example, of course, a big like use cases, musical content.
So in the case of musical content, we want to be compatible with existing models that describe more in detail or the musical concepts.

So we adopted a layered approach so the central concepts are in the middle layer in which we have the central concept that is the audio clip.
Then we have the.

That the clip is something that has been published in our repository and then the signal is the actual audio content of this of this audio clips and the audio files are the media they actually encode.
This signals an these are.
This is the content layer and then you may want to have some more information.
So an especially important for our domain is the the.
And a way to classify this content that could be specific, like a musical domain, like by General Barry Strumentale could be bimodal.
That in this case or other perceptual classifications of sounds that could work in multiple domains.
So we got this layer design categorisation in which we don't include all the specific classifications in the ontology.
But we basically build a mechanist.
With which external classifications may be plugged in in this ontology, and then we have another layer in which we have events that connect these concepts so that the actions.
Basically they allows to convert a signal in an audio clip.
That is, when it's published and this allowed to represent additional metadata, but it's not not in every use case.
And we have to use also the events layer for example, so that allows to have a different level of granularity according to our needs.

Machine consumption through our serialization Zan for human consumption through web page that documents the ontology and there are links to also to download it in several formats and to view it in other online viewers.
Then
With the time remaining, I'm going to talk briefly about the evaluation we're carrying on of this ontology.
So specifically, in the evaluation in our project.
So you know we're projecting parallel to the development of this ontology.

We developed the dedicated software tool to integrate multiple content providers, so this worked basically independently of our ontology, even if it was designed according to similar ideas and concepts.
Because it was related to the requirement from the users, so our evaluation has been to introduce the semantics of our ontology.

Some clients are using this mediator so it's already in use as part of the project.
Then we made another step.
That
We now are using the ontology also for the role of data integration so directly to integrate these different content providers.
So we're using the ontology really as also mediation between these different content providers.
So we have adapters for each content provider that transform, convert the output to an ontology representation of their output, and this is done.
This is done in a pluri, fairly declarative way.
So thanks to do using the ontology into use in appropriate rule languages.
So it's quite a list.
It's our bet that it's easy to to extend and maintain.
OK, so the brief conclusions is that we design it.
This ontology that allows to represent multiple types of audio content.
It goes beyond this bit monolithic object centric model of media resources of other media resources.
Ontologies that are out there.
It uses layered approach to represent multiple levels of granularity and specificity.
This designer then evaluated for usage in concrete scenario.
Specifically in our in our project there's a lot of future work to do, so spend more context of use.
Expand The reach of the of the mediators or the audio comments ecosystem.
The idea is that we have.
Broader reach and build more use cases so that to show the potentials of using the semantics inside this data and evaluate and evolve the ontology or so according to the to the needs.
That's it.
